Samuel and in this episode episode 58
I'm gonna be talking about net
hydrostatic pressure and filtration
pressure so let's get right into it now
we've been looking at the circulatory
system and we've shown that the blood
leaves the heart and then it goes via
the aorta to the arteries and then to
the capillaries to the venules to the
veins and then to the vena cava and then
ultimately back to the heart if you need
a review of that you can always check
out episode 54 where we go into more
detail about that now what we're gonna
be doing today is we're gonna be looking
at what happens between the arterioles
the capillaries and the venules and
that's what we're showing here you have
an artery leaving leading to the
arterial and then that goes through the
capillary bed and then that goes via the
venules to the vein and what we're gonna
look at is what happens specifically
right here the goal here is we want to
get blood coming to the tissues
delivering nutrients and so on oxygen to
the tissues and then taking stuff away
so taking away waste and so on and what
I'm gonna do here is I'm gonna simplify
this a little bit I'm gonna show this
like this I'm gonna take from the
arterioles to the venules and I'm gonna
simplify it showing one arteriole that
connects to one capillary and then
that's gonna connect to one venule okay
so I'm simplifying this significantly
and here we have the arteriole here we
have the venule and here we have the
capillary I'm not gonna put the sea
but here we have the capillary the main
things that we're going to focus on are
the different pressures that we have in
this setup now of course the heart is
pumping and the blood is coming in this
direction and then it's going via the
capillaries and this is where the
exchange happens because this is where
we have the tissue and this is where we
want to get stuff delivered and we want
to pick up stuff to take away from the
tissues so the first thing we're going
to talk about is net hydrostatic
pressure and I'm just gonna write n H P
for net hydrostatic pressure when we're
talking about hydrostatic pressure we
are talking about pressure due to the
fluids and of course in the blood we
have fluids in the tissue we also have
fluids and the net hydrostatic pressure
as the blood is coming in here of course
it's gonna be a blood pressure because
the heart is beating it's pumping the
blood and we've looked at blood pressure
in previous episodes and as the blood
goes through the capillaries there's
gonna be friction that it's encountering
so it's gonna be bumping against the
walls of the capillaries and that's
gonna actually reduce the pressure so
what we're gonna end up with is a high
amount of pressure here and that's gonna
drop down as you go along the
capillaries but not only that we have
tissue here that's filled with fluid
also and that's also gonna exert a
pressure on the capillaries so the net
hydrostatic pressure we're talking about
the total hydrostatic pressure that is
gonna be equal to the blood pressure
okay so the blood is pumping out and
we're gonna subtract the tissue pressure
so the blood pressure how much is
pumping out and how much is pushing in
from the fluids in the tissues and that
net hydrostatic pressure is gonna be
ladies going out closer to the arterial
so we have a lot of hydrostatic pressure
pushing out and as you go down and the
blood is bumping against the walls and
so on that amount of pressure is going
to decrease and this is what I'm
illustrating here it's going down going
down and when you reach to the end
you're gonna have the least amount of
hydrostatic pressure which makes sense
as I said before the blood is coming via
the arteries to the arterioles and it's
coming because the heart is pumping it
and with that pump and you're gonna get
a lot of pressure and that's gonna be
high as here but because this tube is so
small you have a tiny tube almost to the
point that the blood cells can only get
through one at a time that is gonna
cause a lot of friction and that's gonna
decrease the amount of pressure if I
take something and I push it across the
surface because there's gonna be
friction with that surface it's gonna
slow down and that's exactly what we're
getting here the amount of pressure is
gonna decrease as you go away from the
arterioles and towards the venules so
the net hydrostatic pressure is what
we're looking at here no we're gonna get
stuff leaving but not everything can
leave blood cells aren't gonna leave but
water is small enough to get through the
pores in the capillaries so water is
gonna leave it's gonna take some oxygen
with it it's gonna take nutrients with
it and so on and that is gonna leave the
capillaries which is exactly what we
want because we want to deliver that
stuff to the tissues or to the muscles
or to whatever it is this capillary is
going through so this is a good thing
but as the water is leaving of course
you're gonna get less and less water
inside the capillaries and because of
that you're gonna have a change in
osmotic pressure now if you remember
osmosis is the movement
of water across a selectively permeable
membrane and we have a selectively
permeable membrane here so what's gonna
happen is water leaves here there's
gonna be a little bit of osmotic
pressure for water to come back in as
more water leaves you're gonna get an
increase in osmotic pressure and then
you're gonna get it an even greater
increase in osmotic pressure and that's
gonna continue of course and this is
exactly what we're gonna see so as the
net hydrostatic pressure goes down the
osmotic pressure the net osmotic
pressure is gonna increase and increase
and increase and when we take these
together we're gonna get the filtration
pressure I'm gonna write F P and that's
going to be equal to net hydrostatic
pressure minus net osmotic pressure now
these aren't the official symbols this
is just what I'm writing for
simplification but you can see that
we're gonna get a filtration pressure
and if we're over here and we're taking
this hydrostatic pressure minus this
osmotic pressure you're gonna see that
we're gonna have a net filtration
pressure moving stuff out and that's
gonna decrease as we go here to where
the in the center the filtration
pressure is gonna be zero because you
have this amount coming out and this
amount going in and just to make that
more equal I'm just gonna draw the rest
of that arrow here and then of course as
you go down here you have more pressure
going in the osmotic pressure is
significantly greater so you're gonna
get a filtration pressure that's
pointing into the capillaries moving
stuff in so over here we're moving stuff
out over here we're moving stuff in and
if I were to draw a graph I'm just gonna
draw a graph over this
and I'm not sure why I did there is a
dotted line this is the y-axis and we're
dealing with filtration pressure and
let's say this is the zero line what
we're gonna have is a filtration
pressure that looks something like this
here we have it moving out so it's gonna
be somewhere around here
and of course that's gonna go down to
zero
at this point and then continue going
down showing that we have a negative
filtration pressure or in other words a
pressure moving stuff into the
capillaries here is moving out of and
here we're moving stuff into this point
right here where we have a filtration
pressure of zero that is called the
dynamic center okay so this is where the
net hydrostatic pressure is equal to the
net osmotic pressure equal but opposite
of course and that is called a dynamic
center and in a perfect world this
dynamic center is exactly where we want
it to be so that we have a good amount
of distance for stuff to leave and a
good amount of distance for stuff to
come in so we're delivering the
nutrients and the stuff that we need to
the tissue and we're taking away the
waste and the stuff that we don't want
sending that away from the tissues now I
want to look at a different scenario
where we have the same setup we have the
arterial the capillaries and venules
- the veins and vena cava back to the
heart but in this situation we're gonna
be dealing with someone that has high
blood pressure so here we're gonna have
a significant amount of net hydrostatic
pressure pushing stuff out so it's much
higher
and what that's gonna do as you can see
here is the pressures are gonna be
greater all the way along
yes it's decreasing but because we're
starting with a higher amount we're also
gonna end with a higher amount okay now
we also have the osmotic pressure doing
the same thing that it was doing before
and stuff is leaving and let's say we
have it here and this is kind of extreme
and let's say that because of this high
blood pressure we still have the
filtration pressure here we have the
osmotic pressure here but the dynamic
center instead of being over in the
center the dynamic center is somewhere
around here now that is a significant
problem because this is what you have in
this entire section we have fluid
leaving and it's not until here that we
have a net amount of fluid coming in and
what's that's gonna do is it's gonna
cause more fluid to be leaving than the
amount of fluid that's coming in and
that is gonna result in accumulation of
fluid in the tissues or we can also call
that edema so this can be a result of
high blood pressure because we have more
fluid leaving the capillaries then
coming into the capillaries we have more
going towards the tissues and that can
cause a significant amount of problems
resulting in edema so the take-home
message net hydrostatic pressure is
blood pressure minus tissue pressure
that's what we're showing here and if we
want to find the filtration pressure we
take net hydrostatic pressure minus net
osmotic pressure and that will give us
that filtration pressure to this side of
the dynamic center the filtration
pressure is moving fluids and dissolved
molecules out of the capillaries and as
we come to this side
it's moving fluids into the capillaries
if we have high blood pressure that can
shift the dynamic center significantly
resulting in accumulation of the fluids
in the tissues or edema that is pretty
much it for this episode
